## What is Artificial Intelligence?

A more formal definition is given by the National Institute of Standards and Technology in their AI Risk Management Framework (AI RMF 1.0):
## How AI Evolved Over The Years?

- McCullough and Pitts introduced the neuron model which became the foundation of neural networks. The neuron model discussed parallelism between computing machines and the human brain.

- Alan Turing created the Turing test to test the intelligence of a machine.

- A computer program called Logic Theorist was designed to mimic humans' problem-solving skills. Scientist John McCarthy coined the term artificial intelligence.

- Cornell Aeronautical Lab scientist and later Cornell University professor Rosenblatt developed the Perceptron, a machine that could perceive, recognize, and identify its surroundings without human control.

- ELIZA, a natural language program, similar to today's chatbot, was created to handle limited conversation.

- IBM's computer program, Deep Blue beat world chess champion Gary Kasparov.

- IBM's Watson program defeats Jeopardy quiz champions; self-driving cars, virtual assistants (Siri, Alexa...) were introduced.

- Generative AI and Large Language Models revolutionized AI.

 
## What are the subfields of AI?
The term AI can be used for any system mimicking human cognitive skills, such as planning, pattern recognition, and decision-making.

## What are the applications of AI?
There are numerous applications of AI; from healthcare to finance, from designing robots to cybersecurity, from recommender systems to search engines, and so on. Some of the other applications are given below:
- Targeted advertising and personalized recommendations (like Amazon)

- Virtual assistants like Siri and Alexa use AI to understand natural language commands.

- Language translation, speech-to-text, text-to-speech, and summarizing a document are all applications of AI using natural language processing.

- Facial recognition, image/video captioning are examples of AI applications.

- In finance, AI is used for fraud detection and algorithmic trading.

- In healthcare, analysis of biosignals (EEG, ECG, MEG) and imaging (MRI) using AI has helped in understanding the diseases and making better predictions for health.

## What is It?
 is a subset of data mining, using computational methodes to study natural languages as unstructured data sets. It can allow you to explore connections between words and topics.   It can be large blocks of text, not in a table or database.  This research method is increasing in use, but should not be done alone.  It can be called Distant Reading, but you should also do a close reading on a portion of the texts so that you are well informed on the content you are researching. 
## Terminology
Content Mining is the overall concept of pulling together into one place a large corpus of text, data, or images from various sources and running scripts on them to answer a research question. 
- [Text Mining](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Text_mining)is a research technique using computational analysis to uncover patterns in large text-based data sets. (Wikipedia)

- [Data Mining](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_mining)is to use machine-learning and statistical models to uncover clandestine or hidden patterns in a large volume of data (Wikipedia)

- [Webscraping](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_scraping), web harvesting or web data extraction is data scraping used for extracting data from web sites. The term typically refers to automated processes implemented using a bot or web crawler.

- [Machine learning ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning)(ML) is the scientific study of algorithms and statistical models that computer systems use to perform a specific task without using explicit instructions, relying on patterns and inference instead. (Wikipedia)

- Topic Modeling: A form of text mining to identify patterns or topics in a large corpus of text.[(Blei, 2012)](http://www.cs.columbia.edu/~blei/papers/Blei2012.pdf)

- [Natural Language Processing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language_processing)(NLP) is s process of programming computers to process and analyze large amounts of natural language texts.

## Storing and Creating Machine Readable Text
Your data , text, or content must be machine readable and together in one place for the algorthims in any platform to work.  In other words, images like PNG or JPG will not work, so they must be OCRed or converted into text. PDFs may work if the text is searchable within the document.  Here are a few tools for converting your data into the proper text format.  TXT , TSV, or CSV are the best formats for working with data.

## What is Machine Learning?
A machine is said to be if its performance or efficiency for a given task improves with the experience (past data). Machine Learning uses advanced algorithms to analyze and learn relationships between the data to make intelligent decisions on what it has learned. The algorithms use a large amount of data to find the relationship. This relationship is called a which is used to make useful predictions or generate content from the data. 
For example, we need physics-based mathematical equations of Earth's atmosphere to 
predict rainfall using traditional methods. Solving these complex equations requires massive computing resources and time, making the prediction task difficult. With the ML approach, we could provide enormous data to an ML model until the ML model eventually  the mathematical relationship between weather factors producing varying quantities of rain. If we give this model the current weather data, it would predict the amount of rain in the future.

Figure 1 shows the difference between hardcoding the instructions to carry out a specific task versus using ML.

AI system: Recommend songs to EVERYONE based on number of copies sold, top 10 in Billboard list, Grammy award winners, etc.
ML system: Recommend songs to each INDIVIDUAL based on previous songs played, other people with similar playlist, choice of singer, genre, etc.
When using Machine Learning, Neural Networks, or Deep Learning, it is important to know the meaning of the following terms:
- Refers to a specific problem or objective that the algorithm is designed to solve.

- Set of rules that a machine follows to achieve a particular goal or the steps needed to get from the inputs to the output.

- Observed/measured properties or characteristics of the data that are used as input to create a model.

- : Variable whose value isorby the features; used in supervised learning.

- It is theorof the target variable. If only 2 labels (such as 0 or 1, yes/no, hot/warm/cold).

- Subset of data on which the model is initially trained.

- Subset of data (distinct from training) that is used by the model to predict output and validate the model.

- Subset of data (different from training and validation) on which model is tested.
## What are the different types of Machine Learning?
There are 4 major types of ML problems:
- Used for tasks where the target variable has defined labels or values.The target variable has 2 labels (binary class classification) or more (multiclass classification). For example:Whether USA will win or lose a match (binary).Gmail classifying email in classes like social, promotion, updates, or spam (multiclass).The output is numeric and has a continuous value and the task is to predict a value as closer to the actual output value. For example predict stock price of a stock.

- Used for tasks where the target variable or output has no defined labels and hidden patterns in the data are discovered without human intervention.Discovering the inherent groupings in the data such as grouping customers by their purchasing behavior.Discover rules that describe large portions of the data, such as people that buy X also tend to buy Y

- This is a hybrid technique between supervised and unsupervised learning, utilizing both labeled and unlabeled data.

- Learning happens by taking suitable action to maximize reward in a particular situation. It is employed by various software and machines to find the best possible behavior or path to take in a specific situation. If there is no training data, it is bound to learn from its experience. Reward is defined by the experts.

Figure (2) gives the example of  supervised and unsupervised Learning. In figure (2), the classification task is to predict if the user has purchased or not (1 or 0). The regression task is to predict the wind speed.

## HathiTrust Research Center (USC login required)
Supported by Indiana University and University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, HathiTrust Research Center (HTRC) enables computational analysis of works in the HathiTrust Digital Library (HTDL) to facilitate non-profit research and educational use of the collection.
As institutional members of [HathiTrust](https://www.hathitrust.org/), Columbia faculty and students have access to the HathiTrust Research Center. To access this portal, you must first Login to HathiTrust using your USC network id. Once signed in, you can read about the [HathiTrust Research Center here](https://www.hathitrust.org/member-libraries/services-programs/htrc/).  They have freely available text analytics algorithms that you can use on their data by signing up for a [Research Center Analytics account.](https://analytics.hathitrust.org/) These include extracted feature sets, which include metadata from the many volumes in HathiTrust, Topic Modeling, Named Entity Recognizer,and Token Count or Word Clouds.  Also, try the [BookWorm](https://bookworm.htrc.illinois.edu/develop/) .
This wiki page will help you [Get Started ](https://wiki.htrc.illinois.edu/display/COM/Getting+started)with the HathiTrust Research Center.

## AI Use in Developing Manuscripts
Many journals and publishers have developed or are considering policies surrounding the use of AI in developing or authoring manuscripts. You can generally find this information in the Instructions for Authors (or similar) section of the journal. These policies and guidelines are rapidly evolving, so be sure to check regularly for updates.
While journal or publisher policies will always be your final determinant for whether or how you can use AI in developing your manuscript, a few best practices include:
- Be transparent. Disclose and describe the use of AI in developing or author your manuscript.

- Cite your use of the AI tool.

- Be aware that AI can produce incorrect information and generate false citations. Carefully check the accuracy of content generated by the AI tool.

[(Hosseini, M., Rasmussen, L. M., & Resnik, D. B., 2023)](https://doi.org/10.1080/08989621.2023.2168535)
## Citing AI
If you are permitted to use AI in the development of your manuscript, you will need to cite the use of the tool. Citation standards are are still developing and evolving, so be sure to check the appropriate citation guide for guidance. You can visit the Libraries' guide to citation basics for general information, or explore the resources below for statements from MLA, APA, and Chicago. 

- [Citation Basics](https://guides.library.sc.edu/citation)
- [How Do I Cite Generative AI in MLA Style?](https://style.mla.org/citing-generative-ai/)
- [APA Style - How to Cite ChatGPT](https://apastyle.apa.org/blog/how-to-cite-chatgpt)
- [Chicago Manual of Style - Citation, Documentation of Sources](https://www.chicagomanualofstyle.org/qanda/data/faq/topics/Documentation/faq0422.html)

## Licensed Content for Text Analysis
Policies and terms of use for text and data mining of licensed products are subject to change and may be adjusted without notice. Many requests can be mediated through the Libraries, but you may need to negotiate directly with the vendor and pay associated costs. The Libraries does not pay content mining fees for researchers.
The following list is representative of vendor policies but is not exhaustive. Please [contact the Libraries ](mailto:digres@mailbox.sc.edu?subject=Vendor%20Content%20Mining%20Request)for help getting started with these or other databases

- [AM (Adam Matthew)](https://www.amdigital.co.uk/support/digital-humanities)AM allows text and data mining of non-video licensed content subject to written consent from AM for the purposes of research, education, teaching or other non-commercial use. Request access from[AM's website](https://www.amdigital.co.uk/contact/text-and-data-mining).
- [Cambridge University Press](https://www.cambridge.org/digital-products)[Contact the Libraries](mailto:digres@mailbox.sc.edu)to initiate the process.
- [Constellate](https://constellate.org/)
- [Elsevier](https://www.elsevier.com/open-science/research-data/text-and-data-mining)Limited text and data mining may be available for open access content. Contact the Elsevier[Permission Helpdesk](https://service.elsevier.com/app/contact/supporthub/permissions-helpdesk)for other requests.
- [HathiTrust](https://analytics.hathitrust.org/)
- [IEEE](https://www.ieee.org/)Costs negotiated per request.[Contact the Libraries](mailto:digres@mailbox.sc.edu)to initiate process.
- [Newsbank](https://www.newsbank.com/)Restrictions are in place and costs are negotiated for each request.[Contact the Libraries](mailto:digres@mailbox.sc.edu)to initiate the process.
- [Nexis Data](https://www.lexisnexis.com/en-us/products/data-as-a-service/optimal-data-integrations.page)The LexisNexis Web Services API is available to researchers for text and data mining at a cost.[Contact the Libraries](mailto:digres@mailbox.sc.edu)to initiate the process.

Review relevant policies, terms, and conditions from[Sage's website](https://journals.sagepub.com/page/policies/text-and-data-mining).
- [Springer Nature](https://www.springernature.com/gp/researchers/text-and-data-mining)USC researchers may engage in noncommercial text and data mining for research purposes, subject to Springer's policies. An[API key](https://dev.springernature.com/)can be requested.

## Citation Style Guides
Proper citation formats are determined by the particular citation style guide that you are following. Usually your professor will include the required or preferred citation style in your assignment instructions. If you're not sure what style you should use, ask your professor for clarification.
This guide includes examples to help with citation formats in the most commonly used styles:

- [American Medical Association (AMA) 11 ed.](https://guides.library.sc.edu/citation/ama)
- [American Psychological Association (APA) 7th ed.](https://guides.library.sc.edu/citation/apa)
- [Chicago Manual of Style (CMOS) 18th ed.](https://guides.library.sc.edu/citation/chicago)
- [Modern Language Association (MLA) 9th ed.](https://guides.library.sc.edu/citation/mla)
## When and Why to Cite
### Citation Basics
When you directly quote, paraphrase, or reference another source that has influenced your own work, you need to provide a proper citation. You should also provide documentation for any statistics or facts that are not considered common knowledge.
- Avoid charges of plagiarism

- Give credit to the original author or creator

- Provide context for your audience

- Allow readers to find and consult the source themselves
 


[Learn more here](https://guides.library.sc.edu/citation)

## Textbooks and Course Materials
University Libraries gives students access to assigned textbooks and other course
 materials whenever possible, especially for courses with more than 100 students.
### Textbook Collection

Check out textbooks on a first-come, first-served basis at the Checkout Desk on the
 Main Level of Thomas Cooper Library. You must have a valid CarolinaCard. 
The library has a large collection of print textbooks, especially for courses with
 over 100 students. Additional materials are also provided by instructors or the library's
 collections, but the library does not have the assigned textbook for every course
 offered at the university.
Search [Find It @ USC Libraries](https://pascal-usc.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/search?vid=01PASCAL_USCCOL:USC) by book title or course number (ex. HIST112) to see if the library has your assigned
 text. Limit to Course Reserves for better results.
#### Check Out Policy
Generally, you can borrow textbooks for 2 hours and they must stay in the building.
 There are exceptions, and exact due date and time is provided at check out. Renewals
 are not allowed so all students have the opportunity to use these in-demand items.
#### Fines and Blocked Accounts
Returning a textbook late can block you from future textbook check outs.
- Hourly loans for building use only: $5 per hour

- Extended loans for 1 day, 3 days or 1 week: $15 per day

### Other Course Materials
We are working with instructors to make course materials, such as ebooks, online articles
 and streaming films, available in Blackboard whenever possible. Please check [Blackboard](https://blackboard.sc.edu/) or contact your instructor.

While the term  artificial intelligence (AI) has been around since the 1950s and actual AI tools and techniques have been in use since the 1960s, the introduction and rapid growth of generative AI tools and awareness over the past couple years has brought AI out of the lab and into the general experience.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) refers to the simulation of human intelligence in machines or computer systems, enabling them to perform tasks that typically require human intelligence. These tasks include learning, reasoning, problem-solving, understanding natural language, and perceiving their environment. AI systems are designed to analyze and process data, adapt to changing circumstances, and improve their performance over time.
AI can be categorized into two main types:
- Narrow or Weak AI (also known as Artificial Narrow Intelligence - ANI): This type of AI is designed to perform specific tasks or solve particular problems. It is limited in scope and doesn't possess general intelligence or the ability to perform tasks outside of its predefined domain. Examples of narrow AI include virtual personal assistants like Siri and Alexa, recommendation algorithms, and image recognition software.

- General or Strong AI (also known as Artificial General Intelligence - AGI): General AI is a more advanced form of AI that has the ability to understand, learn, and apply knowledge across a wide range of tasks and domains, similar to human intelligence. It is capable of generalizing knowledge and adapting to new situations. General AI, if achieved, would be capable of performing any intellectual task that a human can.

AI technologies encompass a variety of techniques and approaches, including machine learning, deep learning, natural language processing, computer vision, robotics, and more. These technologies are used in various applications, such as self-driving cars, healthcare diagnostics, language translation, gaming, and many other fields, to automate tasks, improve efficiency, and provide new capabilities. AI continues to evolve and has the potential to revolutionize many aspects of society and industry in the coming years.

Artificial intelligence (AI) refers to the theory and development of computer systems that can perform tasks that typically require human intelligence, such as visual perception, speech recognition, decision-making, and language translation. In other words, AI is the ability of machines to mimic human cognitive functions such as learning, reasoning, and problem-solving.
AI is a broad field that encompasses several subfields such as machine learning, natural language processing (NLP), robotics, and computer vision. Machine learning is a subset of AI that involves training algorithms to learn from data and make predictions or decisions without being explicitly programmed. NLP is another subfield of AI that focuses on enabling machines to understand and interpret human language. Robotics involves designing and building robots that can perform tasks autonomously or with minimal human intervention. Computer vision is a subfield of AI that enables machines to interpret and understand visual information from the world around them.
AI has numerous applications across various industries such as healthcare, finance, transportation, and entertainment. For example, AI-powered chatbots can provide customer support services 24/7 without human intervention. In healthcare, AI can be used to diagnose diseases more accurately and efficiently than humans. In finance, AI can be used to detect fraudulent transactions in real-time. In transportation, self-driving cars powered by AI can reduce accidents caused by human error. In entertainment, AI can be used to create personalized recommendations for movies and TV shows based on user preferences.

Artificial intelligence (AI) is the ability of a machine or software to perform tasks that are typically associated with intelligent beings, such as reasoning, learning, and acting autonomously. AI systems are able to process and analyze large amounts of data, and they can use this information to make predictions and decisions.
There are many different types of AI, but some of the most common include:
- : Machine learning algorithms are able to learn from data without being explicitly programmed. This allows them to improve their performance over time without human intervention.

- : Deep learning is a type of machine learning that uses artificial neural networks to learn from data. Neural networks are inspired by the structure and function of the human brain, and they are able to learn complex patterns and relationships in data.

- : NLP is a field of AI that deals with the interaction between computers and human language. NLP systems are able to understand and generate human language, and they can be used for tasks such as machine translation and speech recognition.

AI is already being used in a wide variety of applications, including:
- : AI is being used to develop new drugs and treatments, to diagnose diseases, and to provide personalized care to patients.

- : AI is being used to detect fraud, to predict market trends, and to make investment decisions.

- : AI is being used to develop self-driving cars and trucks, and to optimize traffic flow.

- : AI is being used to develop chatbots and other virtual assistants that can provide customer support 24/7.

- : AI is being used to automate tasks, to improve quality control, and to predict maintenance needs.

AI is a rapidly developing field, and new applications are being discovered all the time. AI has the potential to revolutionize many industries and to improve our lives in many ways.
Here is a more concise definition of AI:
Artificial intelligence (AI) refers to computer systems or machines that are designed to perform tasks that would otherwise require human intelligence, such as visual perception, speech recognition, decision-making, and language translation. The goal of AI research is to develop machines that can mimic and augment human capabilities. Some key capabilities of AI systems include:
- - algorithms that can learn and improve from data without being explicitly programmed. This allows AI systems to adapt and perform better at tasks over time.

- - the ability to process, analyze and understand digital images and videos. This allows AI systems to identify objects, scenes and faces.

- - the ability to understand, interpret and generate human language, including speech recognition, natural language understanding and natural language generation.

- - the ability to perceive environments, manipulate and interact with objects, and perform human-like tasks.

- - the ability to make decisions and take actions that maximize the chances of achieving a specific goal.

So in summary, AI is intelligence demonstrated by machines to mimic cognitive functions associated with human minds, such as learning, problem solving, perception, reasoning and prediction. The overall goal is to create intelligent systems that are capable of assisting humans in a wide variety of tasks and functions.

Generative AI, short for Generative Artificial Intelligence, is a subset of artificial intelligence that focuses on creating or generating new data, content, or artifacts. It's a field within AI that deals with models and algorithms capable of producing original, often human-like, content such as text, images, audio, and more. Generative AI systems work by learning patterns and structures from existing data and then using this knowledge to produce novel, coherent outputs.
There are various techniques and models used in generative AI, including:
- : GANs consist of two neural networks, a generator and a discriminator, which compete with each other. The generator tries to create content (e.g., images) that is indistinguishable from real data, while the discriminator attempts to differentiate between real and generated data. This adversarial training process results in the generation of increasingly convincing content.

- : RNNs are a type of neural network that can generate sequences of data. They are often used in natural language generation and music composition tasks.

- : VAEs are models that learn a probabilistic representation of data, which can be sampled to generate new data points. They are commonly used in image generation and data compression.

- : Transformers are a type of neural network architecture that has been highly successful in natural language processing tasks. Variants like GPT (Generative Pre-trained Transformer) and BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers) are capable of generating human-like text and have applications in text generation, chatbots, and more.

Generative AI has a wide range of practical applications, including:
- : For generating human-like text in chatbots, content generation, and language translation.

- : For creating art, generating images from textual descriptions, and more.

- : Generating music in various styles and genres.

- : Creating characters, levels, and scenarios in video games.

- : Generating molecular structures for potential new drugs.

- : Creating additional data for training machine learning models.

- : Recommending products, movies, or music to users based on their preferences.

While generative AI offers exciting possibilities, it also raises ethical concerns, especially when it comes to generating highly convincing but fake content, often referred to as deepfakes. Researchers and policymakers are actively working on guidelines and regulations to address these challenges in the field of generative AI.
Generative artificial intelligence (generative AI) is a type of artificial intelligence that can create new content such as text, images, code, or other media using generative models. Generative AI models learn the patterns and structure of their input training data and then generate new data that has similar characteristics. 
Generative AI can be used for various purposes such as enhancing creativity, synthesizing data, or manipulating content. For instance, generative AI can be used to create realistic images of non-existent objects or people. It can also be used to generate music or art that is unique and original.
Generative AI is a rapidly growing field with many applications in various industries. For example, it can be used in healthcare to generate synthetic data for research purposes. In finance, it can be used to generate synthetic financial data for fraud detection. In entertainment, it can be used to create personalized content recommendations for users based on their preferences.

 is a type of artificial intelligence that can create new content, such as text, images, music, and code. It does this by learning the patterns and structures in existing data, and then using that knowledge to generate new data that is similar to the original data but not identical.
Generative AI models are typically trained on large datasets of existing data. For example, a text-generating AI model might be trained on a massive dataset of books, articles, and other text data. Once the model is trained, it can be used to generate new text, such as poems, code, scripts, musical pieces, email, letters, etc.
Generative AI has a wide range of potential applications, including:
- : Generative AI can be used to create new and original content, such as news articles, blog posts, social media posts, and marketing materials.

- : Generative AI can be used to design new products, buildings, and other objects.

- : Generative AI can be used to generate synthetic data for research purposes, such as testing new drugs or developing new algorithms.

- : Generative AI can be used to create new forms of entertainment, such as video games, movies, and music.

Generative AI is a rapidly developing field, and new applications are emerging all the time. It is a powerful tool that has the potential to revolutionize many industries and aspects of our lives.
Here are some examples of generative AI models:
- : A large language model that can generate text, translate languages, write different kinds of creative content, and answer your questions in an informative way.

- : A text-to-image diffusion model that can create realistic images and art from text descriptions.

- : A music generation model that can create new musical pieces in a variety of styles.

- : A code generation model that can generate code to solve programming problems.

Generative AI is a powerful tool with the potential to revolutionize many industries and aspects of our lives. However, it is important to note that generative AI models can also be used to create harmful or misleading content, such as deepfakes. It is important to use generative AI responsibly and ethically.
Generative AI refers to a branch of artificial intelligence focused on using machine learning models to generate new content, such as text, images, audio, and video. The key aspects of generative AI include:
- - These are machine learning algorithms trained on large datasets that allow them to identify patterns and generate new sample outputs similar to the training data. Common models include GANs, VAEs, autoregressive models like GPT-3.

- - Models can generate human-like text for a variety of applications like conversational agents, summarization, content creation, and translation. Key techniques include predictive keyboards, autocorrection, autocomplete, and large language models like GPT-3.

- - Models can create realistic images and edit existing images. This has applications in content creation, art generation, manipulating media, and computer vision. Models include GANs, VAEs, diffusion models.

- - Models can synthesize realistic human speech and music. Key applications are text-to-speech, voice cloning, music information retrieval, and voice synthesis for digital assistants.

- - Models can generate artificial but realistic videos and edit existing videos. This has applications in media editing, content creation, and computer vision.

In summary, generative AI leverages the creativity of machine learning models to produce novel, original and realistic content across different media types for a wide variety of applications. It allows systems to go beyond analyzing data to synthesizing and creating new data points.

## Prompt Engineering Defined
Prompt engineering is the practice of designing inputs for generative AI tools that will produce optimal outputs.
## The CLEAR Framework for effective AI prompts
Dr. Leo Lo, Dean of the College of University Libraries & Learning Sciences at the University of New Mexico, has developed a framework for effective AI prompt engineering. The CLEAR framework is comprised of five characteristics.
 Can you provide me with a detailed explanation of the process of photosynthesis and its significance?

## Evaluating Resources Checklist
- [Checklist for Evaluating Web Pages](https://guides.library.sc.edu/ld.php?content_id=76915064)

#### Domain Types and What They Mean
When browsing websites on the internet, pay attention to the domain type at the end of a company/website link - this information can give you a good sense of what to expect from the website or what their biases might be
- AdvocacyPurpose: influence public opinion, sell ideas

- Business/marketingPurpose: promote or sell products

- NewsPurpose: provide extremely current information

- InformationalPurpose: present factual information
#### Criteria 1: Authority
- Is it clear who (organization, institution, or person) isfor the contents?

- Is there a link to a page describing the, the nature of the company, or purpose of the sponsor?

- Is there a way ofof the sponsor? That is, is there a phone number or postal address to contact for more information?

- Is there a statement that the content of the page has theof the sponsor?

- Is it clear whether this is a page from the main sponsor?

- Is there a statement giving the sponsor's name as?
#### Criteria 2: Accuracy
- Are the sources for any factual information clearly listed so they canin another source? (If not, the page may still be useful to you as an example of the ideas of the organization, but it is not useful as a source of factual information)

- Is the information? (These kinds of errors not only indicate a lack of quality control, but can actually produce inaccuracies in information)
#### Criteria 3: Objectivity
- Are the writer's/ sponsor's?

- If there is anyon the page, is it clearly differentiated from the informational content?
#### Criteria 4: Currency
- Are there dates on the page to indicate:When the page was?When the page wason the Web?When the page was?

- Are there any other indications that the material is?
#### Criteria 5: Coverage
- Is there an indication that the page has been, and is not still under construction?

## Generative AI Image/Art generators
### How do AI art generators work?
The goal of an AI art generator is to take a text prompt and turn it into an image that represents the prompt. Comparable to LLMs (large language models), art generators use vast image-text pair content models to discern and learn image meanings and characteristics. Ultimately, they render a resulting image using either a diffusion model or generative adversarial networks (GANS). 
Unlike the major generative AI chatbots, most generative AI art generators have limited or no free access.

- [Dall-E 2](https://openai.com/dall-e-2)
- [Bing Image Creator](https://www.bing.com/create)

## AI Attribution
According to the [APA official blog](https://apastyle.apa.org/blog/how-to-cite-chatgpt), if using AI for editing, data visualization, or other uses, the user should attribute it in the following ways:
- Reference the use and the scenario in the Introduction or Methods section of your paper

- If you are quoting from an AI tool directly, provide the prompt and any text quotedSee[Parenthetical Citation](https://sc.libapps.com/libguides/admin_c.php?g=1370928&p=10133636#s-lg-box-31978749)or[Narrative Citation](https://sc.libapps.com/libguides/admin_c.php?g=1370928&p=10133636#s-lg-box-31978750)for examples

- Include a citation in the Reference section or Sources Cited section of the paperSee the[Reference List](https://sc.libapps.com/libguides/admin_c.php?g=1370928&p=10133636#s-lg-box-31978756)section for an example
